The Providence (R. ~ Journal. after summary
view OF the variety olitems which make up the sum
of General Jacksons uniness for the office OF Presl-
dent, recalls to our memory the following clrcum-
stance which will not be without its effect upon all
minds open to correct impression. We extract II
from the Journal in the terms in which we have found
it. Comment of ours would be superHouus


"After the termination OF the Seminole war. the
conduct of General jackson was ma lie the subject
Of Investigation in the House OF Representatives
and the Senate of the United States Our late dis
tineuished Senator the Hon. James Burrel, was OF
the committee from the Senate. The committee re-
ported, .that they conceive General Jackson to haze
disregarded the posiue orders Of the Waf depart
,nert the Consultation and the Laacs." and "that
he has taken upon himself not only the erercase Of


those popers delegmedto Congress but those enpress-
Ia reserved to the State, in the appointment OF the
etfcers of the militia. 1t will be remembered that
this report was made by honorable and hgh.nlnded
Senator's at a time when no excitement existed a.
gainst the General when he was not before the peo
ole as candidate for any office, when the though


of the Presidency had never even entered his she'll


when encircled by the halo Of military glory, ant


where all the feelings, the prejudlces, and the pas


sions Of the mass of our population were enlisted
his favor. The report was not madesa IRON part.


views or sectional feelings, but from sense OF duty
} With regard TO the conduct of General Jacksontn tn
committee SAYS, were this nation subject to IN


cN of military dospot, and were there no co,ista


tional barriers to the inordinate exercise OF ml ar
ambitions more than this could scarcely hare deen ca
2 pected"
OPINION OF CONGRESS !!

At a respectable meeting of the Citizens of Chris
tiana hundred, friendly to the administration, CON
vened pursuant to public notice at the Buck Inn, on
Wednesday the 26th September,


| JOHN McMINN was called to the chair, and
William Dunnan was appointed Secretary.
| 1t was then upon motion,


| Unanimously Rcsolued That this meeting most
cordially approve of the nomination Of Kensey
| Johns Junr. Esquire, as candidate for the House
of Representatives ofthe United States, and of the
county ticket formed at Clarks corner on the 18th
inst and that we will use all fair and honorable
means to promote the success of the same at the
general election on Tuesday next.
Resolved, That the following persons be appoln-
ted to nominate committee Of vigilance, VIZ: Da-
vid Stdham, James Campbell, Isaac Finn, William
Boyd Robert Pierce, Junr. and Thomas Walters,--


BY whom the following names were reported, and
adopted by the meeting as committee, whose du-
ty it shall be to all due diligence and vigilance
10 bring out the friends of the Administration in this
hundred, on Tuesday next, viz:


David Slidham, William Houston, John A. Ban.
ming, john Haddock, John Siddall VIM. Martin,
James Sidda. James t1addocl1, John McMnn, Thos
Walters, William Rivers, John W alters, James
Campbell, Isaac Finn, George lodson, John Std
ham, William Little, William Boyd, John Logan.
Henry Heald Major William Armstrong, Captain
John Neal, Robert Armstrong, John Armstrong, r.
I. du Pont, Eli sinnex, Peter Williams, John Camp
bell, William Dunnan, Thomas Lyman, Thomas
LYMAN, iunr. Joseph Lyman, Robert P. Robinson,
Jacob Rothwell Ephraim F. Stoops, William Bar
Der, Aaron Justis, George Nebecker, Robert
Pearce. William Houston, junr. William Baldwin,
Peter Hendrckson. Alfred du Pont. Ashton Rich
ardson John Richardson, John Way, Moses Brad
ford, Alexander Gray, Isaac Shallcross, Robert
Crosby, Joseph Richardson, Samuel Richardson
Benjamin HolIingsworth, Jesse Clair, Jacob Pusey
John Holland James McGarvey, Thomas Stanly
Alexander Orr, John G. Phillips, VIM. Stephens
Joseph T. Baily, Henry I4atimer, George McCul-
Tough, Arthur Smith, +. Jeandel, Robert Miller
Henry Cavender, Caleb Kirk, John Rogers, George
Nc cCuough, junr Robert Topham and Peter Hen
erickson, junr.


Resolved, That these proceedings be signed by
the Chairman and Secretary, and published IN the
American Watchnan, the Delaware Journal ant
the Wmingtonian.


Resolved That this meeting now adjourn
4 JOHN McMlNN, Chairman.
VIM. DUNNAN, Sec'y.
CHRISTlANA HUNDRED.

Mr.. Bradford,


We are IA considerable class of persons who have
been uniformly friends of Jackson's election from
principle, who have just discovered, that our new
allies, the Senator's States Attorney, sc. SC. &c.
who have lately joined our ranks and who ought to
be satisfied with moderate share of weight and in
huence in the various arrangements, necessary to
insure success 10 our cause have actually monopo-
lzed the whole concern, and now dictate to US, what
we shall do, with as much confidence as though we
we're their vassas. as individual, have been
an admrer ofGeneral Jackson from the first, and
feel extremely anxious to see him occupy the Pres
dental chair, in which desire know great number
of my fellow citizens in this County cordial and
when the contest shall be alone between Jackson and
Adams, will sacrifice every minor interest to secure
the election of the General but we are not willing
on the present occasion, TO make the sacrifice that is
required of us, and give up the men prefer, SOLE
" to exalt character to the office of Represents
tive to Congress, who to say nothing Of his want o


qualifications and popularity, has been paimed upon
us solely thro management. As already stated, We


are very willing to have the Reads, M Lanes, Ridge


leys sc. sc. &c. as allies, but cannot consent tt
purchase their aid at the expense OF our own indie
peudence. Why has there been SO much shufllng


in fixing on for Congress, when 1t is now pret


ty generally known that Bayar,l was to be the MAJ
from the first? Why did Black and Read refuse II


be taken up, when strongly solicited by their friend
to do so--and why were MIR. Whlteley's feeling
sported with, by being placed on the Ticket?
!; answer-Black and Read were behind the curtains
: they knew all the arrangements--they knew tina
I; whoever was taken up, except Bayard, Was sham
For the Deia,care Journal.
Mr.. Bradford,

Come out from among thean.-Eyery day the eyes
81 some well meaning Jacksonians are opening tol
the true character of the present contest. We'll,
said mun--after he had read il small pamphlet Of
adozen pagcs--s'l have been jackson man, but
am now no longer.''


But this is not solitary instance. There are many.
many instances, in the county OF Newcastle, OF
men who really now convinced that the country
bto gain nothing by the change. '"hey do not ex-
rect any better national policy--but have the
most serious fears that it will be totally different,
were Jackson to succeed. They admire the mill
Mry prowcss Of the General, as they and all men
ought. But they now see that only a few men, and
not the country is to be benefited by a change.
They understand, at length, that the name OF
Jackson is used by many individuals simply to sup
ply their own want of popularity. They see IN the
front ranks in Delaware, not Jackson's original
frends--but new comers-men who denounced the
General-and now support him. because they INA
agne it will be support to themselves


These anl other things are operating upon tht
minds Of two or three hundred citizens Of this coun
ty and every day adds to the number OF those wh'
are taking a more rational view of our public al
fairs. We have always known, and always sad
nothing but time and more knowledge was wantlll
to produce the most salutary changes. The grea


mass of the people on the Opposition side IN tn


State, mean well, and have no personal object


in view. They want only more light, and cand'


view OF the matter, anl hundreds would still be az


ded 10 our numbers.
DELAWARE JOURNAL.

this community, that the Editor Of whom we speak,
is not narvellously troubled with principles OF any
sort. Opinions are his merchandise. and if he has
not always found profitable market for them. he
has doubtless sometimes consoIed himself upon the
consideration OF their quality. We would advise
him never again to oHer reason for change 0f
timent--uhess he should be able to show snbstan-
tia one something that will chink. He is now advo-
! eating the cause OF Gen. jackson Would any
Adams man like to know how to silence his bate.
ry! We can tell them. bGP" Put money in thy
purse"


Ridiculous nonsense! The Enquirer and the
Evening Post To pretend to account for change Of
opinion concerning Gen. jackson. No such change
has taken place. The voice of the men has indeed
changed but false face doth hide what the false
heart doth knows The Enquirer says. 'opinions of
public men constantly liable to change in conse-
quence of the different positions in which they may
be placed."-This sentiment contains just about
that degree of proprety and soundness which might
be expected from man who.


lis every thing by fits and nothing long"


No honest man, orindependent mind would fash.
ferent positions in which they may be placed" The
truth is, in apprehension, that the absure and
most irreconcilabe contradictions which we have
pointed out in the public declarations Of the Post
and Enquirer are chargeable entirely and exclusive
ly to want of any uniform and stable political
principle.


1t is indeed common to change opinions and to
commit errors but we shall not consent, nor will
others, to be dunced so much as to believe
ment that the Editors of the Enquirer and Post know
any thing more now of General Jackson's fitness for
the Presidency than they did some years ago. Then
he was every thing that dangerous, cruel and y-
rannical, and if he was so then he he is so STILL


We doubt not while the Editor is honest in his
zeal, patriotic in what he says. not mercenary but


- ~
such men only as are fit for office. his pages may be
turned over in vain for contradictions which will af
feet his character or call in question his motives Of
yeracity.

aChaage of Opmion."-The spectres Of depar-
ted" opinions which we have recently caused to pass
before the eyes Of the astouoded aud anazea Editor
Of the N. Y. Enquirer have forced from n nun rev
lines on the subject. ssWe all thought" he says,
..Gen Jackson a man of ungovernable passions and
vaultng ambition. and that i not elected. not SOL
it was, if elected he would push on difficulty and
vinence-So, we all thought and sowe all wrote"
The change of opinion is accounted for thus. "il's
conduct at Washington, after being defeated by a
corrupt bargain, dsspated every apprehension N an and
proved u. to be in the wrong " The sum OF all TINS
IS. that because, when the General was defeated IN
the Presidential election .'he did not push on d'ff-
Guilty & violence he is not to be considered "a man
of ungovernabe passions and yaultng amb'to a n
Because he did not set fire to the capital or ovre-
turn the governments he is to be set down as a ve-
ry moderate gentleman, and entitled to govern a
country he has treated with SO much anu
clemency. We do not know how this would sound
in sneech. but it reads bad: So much tor giving
s'reasons upon conpu'sion."


We take to be the generally received opinion Of
r From the National Aauocate.

This day has been very active among the anins'
traon men at this place Three hundred persons atendA
al our meeting Curtis Jacobs and Caleb Rodney acts
ed as charner and w. A. Eigood and @. d. Rodney were

we shall carry our ticket in fine style Mciare hedioith
TO-DAY in shorts long room. He said he had interest
IN the event of the election He expected nohms-ha
hoped for nothing Alas! Alas y!


Next Tuesday will convince the world that there 10
virtue in the people Of Delaware and that no


mans private interest shall pledge the state for Jackson os
any other man. .
/ The most influential Democrats were out to-day we
| shall carry nearly all of The Democratic party

bait to catch gns, and therefore choose TO give
tins honor to Mr.. w. an original jackson man, while
they reserve something more substantial for their
jrasuds. speak the sentiments of many, when |
say, that under all the existing circumstances. we
will throw away our votes4-we cannot vote for
an Administration man, and will not vote for any

Vv;euAs Of the. Administration.

,,ton has been restored to the command Of the ar
,ay. His Grace being now again in place, will, WI
hare say, find good reasons in the next session o
Parliament for adopting the views, respecting tb,
corn laws, of Mr. Huskisson and the rest Of the ca
binet, which SO perplexed him during his brief Sc
cession from power.


Owing to some causes not very Obvious to US Al
This distance, the exchange between England anc
he continent had somewhat suddenly fallen, while
The price Of gold had risen--a concurrence Of cir.
cumstances, that for time appears to have occa-
&ioned pretty serious approximations on the London
schangc, lest it should cause run for gold to be
Exported. The panic, however, for so it had be-
ome was subsidmg by the gradual advance in ex-
change.


OF Greece and Turkey, we find nothing authentic.
-Reports indeed are given, that if true, would in
icae the determination OF the latter not to acguiesce
the meditation Of the Christian powers--but this
Ne fear will only prove, if there be any thing at
Il in it, an empty bfafaao, which VIII not be ser-
lsly maintained.


Spain and Portugal are in an unsettled state. The
minors Of fresh troops from England being under
riers for the latter, are however contradicted pos
lively by tho Courier.


The weather lattcrly had been unEavorable in
England to the gathering in of the harvest-though
n average one was still expected. Much ram had
allen, and the fever and ague so remarkably pre-
aent in our country this season, is, as we learn
uually prevalent in England, and in many parts of
where it was before unknown.


Mr.. Cannings will had been opened, and the pro-
erty sworn to be under 100000 stg.--a sum pro-
ABLY considerably smaller than that which consti-
pted the dover of his wife. He impoverished him
elf in the public service. Ambition, thus dlsner-
kted, is indeed virtue.


From Bells Weekly Messenger


We have mentioned the difficulties under which
Majesty must have abored at this crisis in the
oice of his leading Minister'S and that he had left
tIe or no choice except that which he has so WISE
adopted His Majesty therefore, with promp-
ude which must be highly gratifying to his people,
pld Court at Windsor on Friday. Lord Code
Ri kissed as first Lord of the Treasury, and Mr..
erries. according 10 the Court Circular of yeser
w. received the seals ofoilice as Chancellor of the
Nchcuuer and after also kissing hands, he was
Eorn in member of the Privy Council Lord
in. Bentick went through the same ceremonial as
oyernor General of India, and the Duke of Port
nd was declared Lord President Of the Council.
was then decided that Parliament should be pro-
sneh to the 25th of October.


Ills also with the greatest satisfaction we announce,
at his Grace the Duke of Wellington has accept


his Maiesty's gracious offer OF the Command OF
be Army The communication. we understand, was
pnveycd to his Grace (who is now on the country
II the Marquis of Angesca. The noble Marquis
fturned on Friday night with his Grace's answer,
qifyins his acceptance of the prollered dignity.
e are convinced this communication will be re-
eived by all classes with unmxed pleasure; fol
here never has been second opinionas 10 his being
,e most fit man in whose hands that high trus
hould be reposed. :,


The remaining transfers of office, that OF Mr.
Guskisson from the board Trade to the Coonia
,epartment, ard that Of Mr.. Charles Grant to thu
os now occupied by Mr. Huskisson, could not, o
mrse be formally completed in the absence OF th
If the latter Right Honorable Gentleman.

Sep 60, 1927,
Notice..

Our political Doctors have had very arduous
and extensive practice for the last three months
and with :'hat profit or loss, must be seen on Tues
day next. So much travelling by land and water;
WHAT AILErH THEE, SUSSEX /?

auch constant correspondence such various pres
crptons such vast and .heart-rendeling interes


taken in the welfare Of the patients--all operate
most grieyolsly on the minds and bodies Of thes'
worthy and dsinterested men.


Their attention to the body polite, generally. ha
been great indeed but the lamentabe state of Sus
sex County is most killing concern. Two of thest
doctors left New Castle on Sunday last, and rested
their precious bones, for the night in humble
dwelling in the recesses Of the forest of Kent The
main road was too crooked for them to travel, il
would delay their arrival among the objects Of
their care and love.


most awful Adams fever is raging in Sussex,
and the consequences will be truly amentable, if
the people will not submit to the prescriptions OF
these Doctors. II seems to be in vain that those
good people assure the Doctors that they are in
good health, and want none of their political all
vice and attendance. But the Doctors insist upon
it that theylreay i'll: that they ought to employ
good physicians thatthey, themselves are the only
good ones in the State and that they have left their
homes and travelled from 80 to 100 miles, to cure
this raging fever, purely from pity and compassion.
DIR. Dingle, DR.. Maull, and men of that character.
are deemed very old fashioned sort Of physicians,
who are not able to cure this new and alarming dis
ease. No body is fitted for the purpose except one
who has, at least, smet the shop of the celebrated
Dr. Van Buren, who makes traffic of politics, i'm
proves press, and manufactures panacea for the
most atlroit, consistent, and rapid change Of any
opinion.


Why then, will ye die, o men of Sussex These
doctors love you, and they abour, night and day,
for your welfare They will cure you, without
money and without price. Their bowels yearn over
you with the most heartfelt pity and compassion.
Submit, therefore, to their gentle operations, and
be cured, if not for life, at least for amusement.
Send not home these circumnavisators Of ciarit ,
without taking their pills and their poons, lest they
should tell you to your faces that you are set of
dunderheads, nincompoops, and ninnyhammers.


If ye refuse, with decision and irmness, the Jack
son pills, you will indeed be called upon to sorrow
most of all that you will see their faces no more
How can you doubt their love and their affection
Have they not given you the most positive assuran
ces of it ? Have they not travelled through sands
and forests, through mud and mire, by night and
day, when you has no physicians to heal you !? Say
not that you havebeen be-deviled long enough. Civ
up your opinions to men of more knowledge, & NOR
science, and who will be so afflicted unless you &C
cept their kind and most disinterested services.


While our New Castle county Lawyers are i
Sussex, trying to rectify matters and things, W
hope that the Democratic Jackson men of that cour
ty will ascertain, to their own satisfaction. whethe
the Congressional candidate who is kindly ofere


for their support, is Of such character in all re


spects as they like. Whose candidate is he in rea


lity BY whose influence was he got up? Whose il


huence will he sustain And so forth.


Our accounts from all parts Of the state not on


continue avorabe-but appear more and more
every day-Kensey Johns, j.. the candidate Of tt
. people, whose independence and qualifications a
I, SO Objectionable to the Jackson eleventh hour me
# will be elected by handsome majority, if \
It friends of order and good government will alt e


press their sentiments at the ensuing election.
:. the polls, one and all.


lt s0oo


v For the Delaware Journal

rect any better national policy--but have the
most serious fears that it will be totally different,
were Jackson to succeed. They admire the mill
Mry prowcss Of the General, as they and all men
ought. But they now see that only a few men, and
not the country is to be benefited by a change.
They understand, at length, that the name OF
Jackson is used by many individuals simply to sup
ply their own want of popularity. They see IN the
front ranks in Delaware, not Jackson's original
frends--but new comers-men who denounced the
General-and now support him. because they INA
agne it will be support to themselves


These anl other things are operating upon tht
minds Of two or three hundred citizens Of this coun
ty and every day adds to the number OF those wh'
are taking a more rational view of our public al
fairs. We have always known, and always sad
nothing but time and more knowledge was wantlll
to produce the most salutary changes. The grea


mass of the people on the Opposition side IN tn


State, mean well, and have no personal object


in view. They want only more light, and cand'


view OF the matter, anl hundreds would still be az


ded 10 our numbers.

this community, that the Editor Of whom we speak,
is not narvellously troubled with principles OF any
sort. Opinions are his merchandise. and if he has
not always found profitable market for them. he
has doubtless sometimes consoIed himself upon the
consideration OF their quality. We would advise
him never again to oHer reason for change 0f
timent--uhess he should be able to show snbstan-
tia one something that will chink. He is now advo-
! eating the cause OF Gen. jackson Would any
Adams man like to know how to silence his bate.
ry! We can tell them. bGP" Put money in thy
purse"


Ridiculous nonsense! The Enquirer and the
Evening Post To pretend to account for change Of
opinion concerning Gen. jackson. No such change
has taken place. The voice of the men has indeed
changed but false face doth hide what the false
heart doth knows The Enquirer says. 'opinions of
public men constantly liable to change in conse-
quence of the different positions in which they may
be placed."-This sentiment contains just about
that degree of proprety and soundness which might
be expected from man who.


lis every thing by fits and nothing long"


No honest man, orindependent mind would fash.
ferent positions in which they may be placed" The
truth is, in apprehension, that the absure and
most irreconcilabe contradictions which we have
pointed out in the public declarations Of the Post
and Enquirer are chargeable entirely and exclusive
ly to want of any uniform and stable political
principle.


1t is indeed common to change opinions and to
commit errors but we shall not consent, nor will
others, to be dunced so much as to believe
ment that the Editors of the Enquirer and Post know
any thing more now of General Jackson's fitness for
the Presidency than they did some years ago. Then
he was every thing that dangerous, cruel and y-
rannical, and if he was so then he he is so STILL


We doubt not while the Editor is honest in his
zeal, patriotic in what he says. not mercenary but


- ~
such men only as are fit for office. his pages may be
turned over in vain for contradictions which will af
feet his character or call in question his motives Of
yeracity.

full articles.article:
aChaage of Opmion."-The spectres Of depar-
ted" opinions which we have recently caused to pass
before the eyes Of the astouoded aud anazea Editor
Of the N. Y. Enquirer have forced from n nun rev
lines on the subject. ssWe all thought" he says,
..Gen Jackson a man of ungovernable passions and
vaultng ambition. and that i not elected. not SOL
it was, if elected he would push on difficulty and
vinence-So, we all thought and sowe all wrote"
The change of opinion is accounted for thus. "il's
conduct at Washington, after being defeated by a
corrupt bargain, dsspated every apprehension N an and
proved u. to be in the wrong " The sum OF all TINS
IS. that because, when the General was defeated IN
the Presidential election .'he did not push on d'ff-
Guilty & violence he is not to be considered "a man
of ungovernabe passions and yaultng amb'to a n
Because he did not set fire to the capital or ovre-
turn the governments he is to be set down as a ve-
ry moderate gentleman, and entitled to govern a
country he has treated with SO much anu
clemency. We do not know how this would sound
in sneech. but it reads bad: So much tor giving
s'reasons upon conpu'sion."


We take to be the generally received opinion Of

Extract of letter dated Georgetowu Dell Sept 49, IS n


This day has been very active among the anins'
traon men at this place Three hundred persons atendA
al our meeting Curtis Jacobs and Caleb Rodney acts
ed as charner and w. A. Eigood and @. d. Rodney were
appointed secretaries Our aa,alsamation ticket ls-~
K Johs r for Congress Senator-samuei Paynter. he-
b,esentatues-L. Riley, G 5. Layton, NJ tmda'l, dohh
.rennant kendal NJ. Laws r. Burton and J. VibankA-
we shall carry our ticket in fine style Mciare hedioith
TO-DAY in shorts long room. He said he had interest
IN the event of the election He expected nohms-ha
hoped for nothing Alas! Alas y!


Next Tuesday will convince the world that there 10
virtue in the people Of Delaware and that no


mans private interest shall pledge the state for Jackson os
any other man. .
/ The most influential Democrats were out to-day we
| shall carry nearly all of The Democratic party

bait to catch gns, and therefore choose TO give
tins honor to Mr.. w. an original jackson man, while
they reserve something more substantial for their
jrasuds. speak the sentiments of many, when |
say, that under all the existing circumstances. we
will throw away our votes4-we cannot vote for
an Administration man, and will not vote for any
man palmed upon US by set Of would-be-lords.

Sep. 81. 1927

,,ton has been restored to the command Of the ar
,ay. His Grace being now again in place, will, WI
hare say, find good reasons in the next session o
Parliament for adopting the views, respecting tb,
corn laws, of Mr. Huskisson and the rest Of the ca
binet, which SO perplexed him during his brief Sc
cession from power.


Owing to some causes not very Obvious to US Al
This distance, the exchange between England anc
he continent had somewhat suddenly fallen, while
The price Of gold had risen--a concurrence Of cir.
cumstances, that for time appears to have occa-
&ioned pretty serious approximations on the London
schangc, lest it should cause run for gold to be
Exported. The panic, however, for so it had be-
ome was subsidmg by the gradual advance in ex-
change.


OF Greece and Turkey, we find nothing authentic.
-Reports indeed are given, that if true, would in
icae the determination OF the latter not to acguiesce
the meditation Of the Christian powers--but this
Ne fear will only prove, if there be any thing at
Il in it, an empty bfafaao, which VIII not be ser-
lsly maintained.


Spain and Portugal are in an unsettled state. The
minors Of fresh troops from England being under
riers for the latter, are however contradicted pos
lively by tho Courier.


The weather lattcrly had been unEavorable in
England to the gathering in of the harvest-though
n average one was still expected. Much ram had
allen, and the fever and ague so remarkably pre-
aent in our country this season, is, as we learn
uually prevalent in England, and in many parts of
where it was before unknown.


Mr.. Cannings will had been opened, and the pro-
erty sworn to be under 100000 stg.--a sum pro-
ABLY considerably smaller than that which consti-
pted the dover of his wife. He impoverished him
elf in the public service. Ambition, thus dlsner-
kted, is indeed virtue.


From Bells Weekly Messenger


We have mentioned the difficulties under which
Majesty must have abored at this crisis in the
oice of his leading Minister'S and that he had left
tIe or no choice except that which he has so WISE
adopted His Majesty therefore, with promp-
ude which must be highly gratifying to his people,
pld Court at Windsor on Friday. Lord Code
Ri kissed as first Lord of the Treasury, and Mr..
erries. according 10 the Court Circular of yeser
w. received the seals ofoilice as Chancellor of the
Nchcuuer and after also kissing hands, he was
Eorn in member of the Privy Council Lord
in. Bentick went through the same ceremonial as
oyernor General of India, and the Duke of Port
nd was declared Lord President Of the Council.
was then decided that Parliament should be pro-
sneh to the 25th of October.


Ills also with the greatest satisfaction we announce,
at his Grace the Duke of Wellington has accept


his Maiesty's gracious offer OF the Command OF
be Army The communication. we understand, was
pnveycd to his Grace (who is now on the country
II the Marquis of Angesca. The noble Marquis
fturned on Friday night with his Grace's answer,
qifyins his acceptance of the prollered dignity.
e are convinced this communication will be re-
eived by all classes with unmxed pleasure; fol
here never has been second opinionas 10 his being
,e most fit man in whose hands that high trus
hould be reposed. :,


The remaining transfers of office, that OF Mr.
Guskisson from the board Trade to the Coonia
,epartment, ard that Of Mr.. Charles Grant to thu
os now occupied by Mr. Huskisson, could not, o
mrse be formally completed in the absence OF th
If the latter Right Honorable Gentleman.

full articles.headline: WHAT AILErH THEE, SUSSEX /?
full articles.article:
Our political Doctors have had very arduous
and extensive practice for the last three months
and with :'hat profit or loss, must be seen on Tues
day next. So much travelling by land and water;

auch constant correspondence such various pres
crptons such vast and .heart-rendeling interes


taken in the welfare Of the patients--all operate
most grieyolsly on the minds and bodies Of thes'
worthy and dsinterested men.


Their attention to the body polite, generally. ha
been great indeed but the lamentabe state of Sus
sex County is most killing concern. Two of thest
doctors left New Castle on Sunday last, and rested
their precious bones, for the night in humble
dwelling in the recesses Of the forest of Kent The
main road was too crooked for them to travel, il
would delay their arrival among the objects Of
their care and love.


most awful Adams fever is raging in Sussex,
and the consequences will be truly amentable, if
the people will not submit to the prescriptions OF
these Doctors. II seems to be in vain that those
good people assure the Doctors that they are in
good health, and want none of their political all
vice and attendance. But the Doctors insist upon
it that theylreay i'll: that they ought to employ
good physicians thatthey, themselves are the only
good ones in the State and that they have left their
homes and travelled from 80 to 100 miles, to cure
this raging fever, purely from pity and compassion.
DIR. Dingle, DR.. Maull, and men of that character.
are deemed very old fashioned sort Of physicians,
who are not able to cure this new and alarming dis
ease. No body is fitted for the purpose except one
who has, at least, smet the shop of the celebrated
Dr. Van Buren, who makes traffic of politics, i'm
proves press, and manufactures panacea for the
most atlroit, consistent, and rapid change Of any
opinion.


Why then, will ye die, o men of Sussex These
doctors love you, and they abour, night and day,
for your welfare They will cure you, without
money and without price. Their bowels yearn over
you with the most heartfelt pity and compassion.
Submit, therefore, to their gentle operations, and
be cured, if not for life, at least for amusement.
Send not home these circumnavisators Of ciarit ,
without taking their pills and their poons, lest they
should tell you to your faces that you are set of
dunderheads, nincompoops, and ninnyhammers.


If ye refuse, with decision and irmness, the Jack
son pills, you will indeed be called upon to sorrow
most of all that you will see their faces no more
How can you doubt their love and their affection
Have they not given you the most positive assuran
ces of it ? Have they not travelled through sands
and forests, through mud and mire, by night and
day, when you has no physicians to heal you !? Say
not that you havebeen be-deviled long enough. Civ
up your opinions to men of more knowledge, & NOR
science, and who will be so afflicted unless you &C
cept their kind and most disinterested services.


While our New Castle county Lawyers are i
Sussex, trying to rectify matters and things, W
hope that the Democratic Jackson men of that cour
ty will ascertain, to their own satisfaction. whethe
the Congressional candidate who is kindly ofere


for their support, is Of such character in all re


spects as they like. Whose candidate is he in rea


lity BY whose influence was he got up? Whose il


huence will he sustain And so forth.


Our accounts from all parts Of the state not on


continue avorabe-but appear more and more
every day-Kensey Johns, j.. the candidate Of tt
. people, whose independence and qualifications a
I, SO Objectionable to the Jackson eleventh hour me
# will be elected by handsome majority, if \
It friends of order and good government will alt e


press their sentiments at the ensuing election.
:. the polls, one and all.


lt s0oo


v For the Delaware Journal
< Mr. Bradford,


70 We are considerable class Of persons who ha
